trans-unit.source: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: using SQL Server | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: using SQL Server | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action
trans-unit.target: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you walkthrough building and deploying a model using a publicly available dataset -- the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you walkthrough building and deploying a model using a publicly available dataset -- the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset.

trans-unit.source: The procedure follows the Azure Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) guide.
trans-unit.target: The procedure follows the Azure Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) guide.

trans-unit.source: The NYC Taxi Trip data is about 20GB of compressed CSV files (~48GB uncompressed), comprising more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.
trans-unit.target: The NYC Taxi Trip data is about 20GB of compressed CSV files (~48GB uncompressed), comprising more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.

trans-unit.source: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off location and time, anonymized hack (driver's) license number and medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.
trans-unit.target: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off location and time, anonymized hack (driver's) license number and medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.

trans-unit.source: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:
trans-unit.target: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:

trans-unit.source: The 'trip_data' CSV contains trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.
trans-unit.target: The 'trip_data' CSV contains trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The 'trip_fare' CSV contains details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.
trans-unit.target: The 'trip_fare' CSV contains details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The unique key to join trip\data and trip\fare is composed of the fields: medallion, hack\licence and pickup\datetime.
trans-unit.target: The unique key to join trip\data and trip\fare is composed of the fields: medallion, hack\licence and pickup\datetime.

trans-unit.source: We will formulate three prediction problems based on the tip\_amount, namely:
trans-unit.target: We will formulate three prediction problems based on the tip\_amount, namely:

trans-unit.source: Binary classification: Predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a tip\_amount that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a tip\_amount of $0 is a negative example.
trans-unit.target: Binary classification: Predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a tip\_amount that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a tip\_amount of $0 is a negative example.

trans-unit.source: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip paid for the trip.
trans-unit.target: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip paid for the trip.

trans-unit.source: We divide the tip\_amount into five bins or classes:
trans-unit.target: We divide the tip\_amount into five bins or classes:

trans-unit.source: Regression task: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Regression task: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: As you can see from the <linkText>Plan Your Environment</linkText><title></title> guide, there are several options to work with the NYC Taxi Trips dataset in Azure:
trans-unit.target: As you can see from the <linkText>Plan Your Environment</linkText><title></title> guide, there are several options to work with the NYC Taxi Trips dataset in Azure:

trans-unit.source: Work with the data in Azure blobs then model in Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Work with the data in Azure blobs then model in Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: Load the data into a SQL Server database then model in Azure Machine Learning
trans-unit.target: Load the data into a SQL Server database then model in Azure Machine Learning

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we will demonstrate parallel bulk import of the data to a SQL Server, data exploration, feature engineering and down sampling using SQL Server Management Studio as well as using IPython Notebook.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we will demonstrate parallel bulk import of the data to a SQL Server, data exploration, feature engineering and down sampling using SQL Server Management Studio as well as using IPython Notebook.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Sample scripts</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>IPython notebooks</linkText><title></title> are shared in GitHub.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Sample scripts</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>IPython notebooks</linkText><title></title> are shared in GitHub.

trans-unit.source: A sample IPython notebook to work with the data in Azure blobs is also available in the same location.
trans-unit.target: A sample IPython notebook to work with the data in Azure blobs is also available in the same location.

trans-unit.source: To set up your Azure Data Science environment:
trans-unit.target: To set up your Azure Data Science environment:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Provision a Data Science Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title>, which will serve as a SQL Server as well an IPython Notebook server.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Provision a Data Science Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title>, which will serve as a SQL Server as well an IPython Notebook server.

trans-unit.source: The sample scripts and IPython notebooks will be downloaded to your Data Science virtual machine during the setup process.
trans-unit.target: The sample scripts and IPython notebooks will be downloaded to your Data Science virtual machine during the setup process.

trans-unit.source: When the VM post-installation script completes, the samples will be in your VM's Documents library:
trans-unit.target: When the VM post-installation script completes, the samples will be in your VM's Documents library:

trans-unit.source: Sample Scripts: C:\Users\\Documents\Data Science Scripts
trans-unit.target: Sample Scripts: C:\Users\\Documents\Data Science Scripts

trans-unit.source: Sample IPython Notebooks: C:\Users\\Documents\IPython Notebooks\DataScienceSamples where is your VM's Windows login name. We will refer to the sample folders as Sample Scripts and Sample IPython Notebooks.
trans-unit.target: Sample IPython Notebooks: C:\Users\\Documents\IPython Notebooks\DataScienceSamples where is your VM's Windows login name. We will refer to the sample folders as Sample Scripts and Sample IPython Notebooks.

trans-unit.source: Based on the dataset size, data source location, and the selected Azure target environment, this scenario is similar to <linkText>Scenario \#5: Large dataset in a local files, target SQL Server in Azure VM</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Based on the dataset size, data source location, and the selected Azure target environment, this scenario is similar to <linkText>Scenario \#5: Large dataset in a local files, target SQL Server in Azure VM</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To get the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset from its public location, you may use any of the methods described in <linkText>Move Data to and from Azure Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to copy the data to your new virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: To get the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset from its public location, you may use any of the methods described in <linkText>Move Data to and from Azure Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to copy the data to your new virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: To copy the data using AzCopy:
trans-unit.target: To copy the data using AzCopy:

trans-unit.source: Log in to your virtual machine (VM)
trans-unit.target: Log in to your virtual machine (VM)

trans-unit.source: Create a new directory in the VM's data disk (Note: Do not use the Temporary Disk which comes with the VM as a Data Disk).
trans-unit.target: Create a new directory in the VM's data disk (Note: Do not use the Temporary Disk which comes with the VM as a Data Disk).

trans-unit.source: In a Command Prompt window, run the following Azcopy command line, replacing todata_folder> with your data folder created in (2):
trans-unit.target: In a Command Prompt window, run the following Azcopy command line, replacing todata_folder> with your data folder created in (2):

trans-unit.source: When the AzCopy completes, a total of 24 zipped CSV files (12 for trip\data and 12 for trip\fare) should be in the data folder.
trans-unit.target: When the AzCopy completes, a total of 24 zipped CSV files (12 for trip\data and 12 for trip\fare) should be in the data folder.

trans-unit.source: Unzip the downloaded files. Note the folder where the uncompressed files reside. This folder will be referred to as the to\data\_files\>.
trans-unit.target: Unzip the downloaded files. Note the folder where the uncompressed files reside. This folder will be referred to as the to\data\_files\>.

trans-unit.source: The performance of loading/transferring large amounts of data to an SQL database and subsequent queries can be improved by using Partitioned Tables and Views.
trans-unit.target: The performance of loading/transferring large amounts of data to an SQL database and subsequent queries can be improved by using Partitioned Tables and Views.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will follow the instructions described in <linkText>Parallel Bulk Data Import Using SQL Partition Tables</linkText><title></title> to create a new database and load the data into partitioned tables in parallel.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will follow the instructions described in <linkText>Parallel Bulk Data Import Using SQL Partition Tables</linkText><title></title> to create a new database and load the data into partitioned tables in parallel.

trans-unit.source: While logged in to your VM, start SQL Server Management Studio.
trans-unit.target: While logged in to your VM, start SQL Server Management Studio.

trans-unit.source: Connect using Windows Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Connect using Windows Authentication.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SSMS Connect</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SSMS Connect</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you have not yet changed the SQL Server authentication mode and created a new SQL login user, open the script file named change\_auth.sql in the Sample Scripts folder.
trans-unit.target: If you have not yet changed the SQL Server authentication mode and created a new SQL login user, open the script file named change\_auth.sql in the Sample Scripts folder.

trans-unit.source: Change the default user name and password.
trans-unit.target: Change the default user name and password.

trans-unit.source: Click !Execute in the toolbar to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Click !Execute in the toolbar to run the script.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Execute Script</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Execute Script</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Verify and/or change the SQL Server default database and log folders to ensure that newly created databases will be stored in a Data Disk.
trans-unit.target: Verify and/or change the SQL Server default database and log folders to ensure that newly created databases will be stored in a Data Disk.

trans-unit.source: The SQL Server VM image that is optimized for datawarehousing loads is pre-configured with data and log disks.
trans-unit.target: The SQL Server VM image that is optimized for datawarehousing loads is pre-configured with data and log disks.

trans-unit.source: If your VM did not include a Data Disk and you added new virtual hard disks during the VM setup process, change the default folders as follows:
trans-unit.target: If your VM did not include a Data Disk and you added new virtual hard disks during the VM setup process, change the default folders as follows:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the SQL Server name in the left panel and click Properties.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the SQL Server name in the left panel and click Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Server Properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Server Properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Database Settings from the Select a page list to the left.
trans-unit.target: Select Database Settings from the Select a page list to the left.

trans-unit.source: Verify and/or change the Database default locations to the Data Disk locations of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Verify and/or change the Database default locations to the Data Disk locations of your choice.

trans-unit.source: This is where new databases reside if created with the default location settings.
trans-unit.target: This is where new databases reside if created with the default location settings.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQL Database Defaults</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQL Database Defaults</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To create a new database and a set of filegroups to hold the partitioned tables, open the sample script create\_db\_default.sql.
trans-unit.target: To create a new database and a set of filegroups to hold the partitioned tables, open the sample script create\_db\_default.sql.

trans-unit.source: The script will create a new database named TaxiNYC and 12 filegroups in the default data location.
trans-unit.target: The script will create a new database named TaxiNYC and 12 filegroups in the default data location.

trans-unit.source: Each filegroup will hold one month of trip\data and trip\fare data.
trans-unit.target: Each filegroup will hold one month of trip\data and trip\fare data.

trans-unit.source: Modify the database name, if desired.
trans-unit.target: Modify the database name, if desired.

trans-unit.source: Click !Execute to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Click !Execute to run the script.

trans-unit.source: Next, create two partition tables, one for the trip\data and another for the trip\fare.
trans-unit.target: Next, create two partition tables, one for the trip\data and another for the trip\fare.

trans-unit.source: Open the sample script create\_partitioned\_table.sql, which will:
trans-unit.target: Open the sample script create\_partitioned\_table.sql, which will:

trans-unit.source: Create a partition function to split the data by month.
trans-unit.target: Create a partition function to split the data by month.

trans-unit.source: Create a partition scheme to map each month's data to a different filegroup.
trans-unit.target: Create a partition scheme to map each month's data to a different filegroup.

trans-unit.source: Create two partitioned tables mapped to the partition scheme: nyctaxi\_trip will hold the trip\_data and nyctaxi\_fare will hold the trip\_fare data.
trans-unit.target: Create two partitioned tables mapped to the partition scheme: nyctaxi\_trip will hold the trip\_data and nyctaxi\_fare will hold the trip\_fare data.

trans-unit.source: Click !Execute to run the script and create the partitioned tables.
trans-unit.target: Click !Execute to run the script and create the partitioned tables.

trans-unit.source: In the Sample Scripts folder, there are two sample PowerShell scripts provided to demonstrate parallel bulk imports of data to SQL Server tables.
trans-unit.target: In the Sample Scripts folder, there are two sample PowerShell scripts provided to demonstrate parallel bulk imports of data to SQL Server tables.

trans-unit.source: bcp\_parallel\_generic.ps1 is a generic script to parallel bulk import data into a table.
trans-unit.target: bcp\_parallel\_generic.ps1 is a generic script to parallel bulk import data into a table.

trans-unit.source: Modify this script to set the input and target variables as indicated in the comment lines in the script.
trans-unit.target: Modify this script to set the input and target variables as indicated in the comment lines in the script.

trans-unit.source: bcp\_parallel\_nyctaxi.ps1 is a pre-configured version of the generic script and can be used to to load both tables for the NYC Taxi Trips data.
trans-unit.target: bcp\_parallel\_nyctaxi.ps1 is a pre-configured version of the generic script and can be used to to load both tables for the NYC Taxi Trips data.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the bcp\_parallel\_nyctaxi.ps1 script name and click Edit to open it in PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the bcp\_parallel\_nyctaxi.ps1 script name and click Edit to open it in PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Review the preset variables and modify according to your selected database name, input data folder, target log folder, and paths to the sample format files nyctaxi_trip.xml and nyctaxi\_fare.xml (provided in the Sample Scripts folder).
trans-unit.target: Review the preset variables and modify according to your selected database name, input data folder, target log folder, and paths to the sample format files nyctaxi_trip.xml and nyctaxi\_fare.xml (provided in the Sample Scripts folder).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Bulk Import Data</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Bulk Import Data</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You may also select the authentication mode, default is Windows Authentication.
trans-unit.target: You may also select the authentication mode, default is Windows Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Click the green arrow in the toolbar to run.
trans-unit.target: Click the green arrow in the toolbar to run.

trans-unit.source: The script will launch 24 bulk import operations in parallel, 12 for each partitioned table.
trans-unit.target: The script will launch 24 bulk import operations in parallel, 12 for each partitioned table.

trans-unit.source: You may monitor the data import progress by opening the SQL Server default data folder as set above.
trans-unit.target: You may monitor the data import progress by opening the SQL Server default data folder as set above.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell script reports the starting and ending times.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell script reports the starting and ending times.

trans-unit.source: When all bulk imports complete, the ending time is reported.
trans-unit.target: When all bulk imports complete, the ending time is reported.

trans-unit.source: Check the target log folder to verify that the bulk imports were successful, i.e., no errors reported in the target log folder.
trans-unit.target: Check the target log folder to verify that the bulk imports were successful, i.e., no errors reported in the target log folder.

trans-unit.source: Your database is now ready for exploration, feature engineering, and other operations as desired.
trans-unit.target: Your database is now ready for exploration, feature engineering, and other operations as desired.

trans-unit.source: Since the tables are partitioned according to the pickup\_datetime field, queries which include pickup\_datetime conditions in the WHERE clause will benefit from the partition scheme.
trans-unit.target: Since the tables are partitioned according to the pickup\_datetime field, queries which include pickup\_datetime conditions in the WHERE clause will benefit from the partition scheme.

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Management Studio, explore the provided sample script sample\_queries.sql.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Management Studio, explore the provided sample script sample\_queries.sql.

trans-unit.source: To run any of the sample queries, highlight the query lines then click !Execute in the toolbar.
trans-unit.target: To run any of the sample queries, highlight the query lines then click !Execute in the toolbar.

trans-unit.source: The NYC Taxi Trips data is loaded in two separate tables.
trans-unit.target: The NYC Taxi Trips data is loaded in two separate tables.

trans-unit.source: To improve join operations, it is highly recommended to index the tables.
trans-unit.target: To improve join operations, it is highly recommended to index the tables.

trans-unit.source: The sample script create\_partitioned\_index.sql creates partitioned indexes on the composite join key medallion, hack\_license, and pickup\_datetime.
trans-unit.target: The sample script create\_partitioned\_index.sql creates partitioned indexes on the composite join key medallion, hack\_license, and pickup\_datetime.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation by running SQL queries directly in the SQL Server Management Studio using the SQL Server database created earlier.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation by running SQL queries directly in the SQL Server Management Studio using the SQL Server database created earlier.

trans-unit.source: A sample script named sample\_queries.sql is provided in the Sample Scripts folder.
trans-unit.target: A sample script named sample\_queries.sql is provided in the Sample Scripts folder.

trans-unit.source: Modify the script to change the database name, if it is different from the default: TaxiNYC.
trans-unit.target: Modify the script to change the database name, if it is different from the default: TaxiNYC.

trans-unit.source: In this exercise, we will:
trans-unit.target: In this exercise, we will:

trans-unit.source: Connect to SQL Server Management Studio using either Windows Authentication or using SQL Authentication and the SQL login name and password.
trans-unit.target: Connect to SQL Server Management Studio using either Windows Authentication or using SQL Authentication and the SQL login name and password.

trans-unit.source: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.
trans-unit.target: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.

trans-unit.source: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.
trans-unit.target: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.

trans-unit.source: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the tip\_amount.
trans-unit.target: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the tip\_amount.

trans-unit.source: Generate features and compute/compare trip distances.
trans-unit.target: Generate features and compute/compare trip distances.

trans-unit.source: Join the two tables and extract a random sample that will be used to build models.
trans-unit.target: Join the two tables and extract a random sample that will be used to build models.

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:

trans-unit.source: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning, or
trans-unit.target: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning, or

trans-unit.source: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new database table and use the new table in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new database table and use the new table in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: In this section we will save the final query to extract and sample the data.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will save the final query to extract and sample the data.

trans-unit.source: The second method is demonstrated in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in IPython Notebook</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: The second method is demonstrated in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in IPython Notebook</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: For a quick verification of the number of rows and columns in the tables populated earlier using parallel bulk import,
trans-unit.target: For a quick verification of the number of rows and columns in the tables populated earlier using parallel bulk import,

trans-unit.source: This example identifies the medallion (taxi numbers) with more than 100 trips within a given time period.
trans-unit.target: This example identifies the medallion (taxi numbers) with more than 100 trips within a given time period.

trans-unit.source: The query would benefit from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition scheme of pickup\_datetime.
trans-unit.target: The query would benefit from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition scheme of pickup\_datetime.

trans-unit.source: Querying the full dataset will also make use of the partitioned table and/or index scan.
trans-unit.target: Querying the full dataset will also make use of the partitioned table and/or index scan.

trans-unit.source: This example investigates if any of the longitude and/or latitude fields either contain an invalid value (radian degrees should be between -90 and 90), or have (0, 0) coordinates.
trans-unit.target: This example investigates if any of the longitude and/or latitude fields either contain an invalid value (radian degrees should be between -90 and 90), or have (0, 0) coordinates.

trans-unit.source: This example finds the number of trips that were tipped vs. not tipped in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).
trans-unit.target: This example finds the number of trips that were tipped vs. not tipped in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).

trans-unit.source: This distribution reflects the binary label distribution to be later used for binary classification modeling.
trans-unit.target: This distribution reflects the binary label distribution to be later used for binary classification modeling.

trans-unit.source: This example computes the distribution of tip ranges in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).
trans-unit.target: This example computes the distribution of tip ranges in a given time period (or in the full dataset if covering the full year).

trans-unit.source: This is the distribution of the label classes that will be used later for multiclass classification modeling.
trans-unit.target: This is the distribution of the label classes that will be used later for multiclass classification modeling.

trans-unit.source: This example converts the pickup and drop-off longitude and latitude to SQL geography points, computes the trip distance using SQL geography points difference, and returns a random sample of the results for comparison.
trans-unit.target: This example converts the pickup and drop-off longitude and latitude to SQL geography points, computes the trip distance using SQL geography points difference, and returns a random sample of the results for comparison.

trans-unit.source: The example limits the results to valid coordinates only using the data quality assessment query covered earlier.
trans-unit.target: The example limits the results to valid coordinates only using the data quality assessment query covered earlier.

trans-unit.source: The label generation and geography conversion exploration queries can also be used to generate labels/features by removing the counting part.
trans-unit.target: The label generation and geography conversion exploration queries can also be used to generate labels/features by removing the counting part.

trans-unit.source: Additional feature engineering SQL examples are provided in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in IPython Notebook</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: Additional feature engineering SQL examples are provided in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in IPython Notebook</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: It is more efficient to run the feature generation queries on the full dataset or a large subset of it using SQL queries which run directly on the SQL Server database instance.
trans-unit.target: It is more efficient to run the feature generation queries on the full dataset or a large subset of it using SQL queries which run directly on the SQL Server database instance.

trans-unit.source: The queries may be executed in SQL Server Management Studio, IPython Notebook or any development tool/environment which can access the database locally or remotely.
trans-unit.target: The queries may be executed in SQL Server Management Studio, IPython Notebook or any development tool/environment which can access the database locally or remotely.

trans-unit.source: The following query joins the nyctaxi\_trip and nyctaxi\_fare tables, generates a binary classification label tipped, a multi-class classification label tip\_class, and extracts a 1% random sample from the full joined dataset.
trans-unit.target: The following query joins the nyctaxi\_trip and nyctaxi\_fare tables, generates a binary classification label tipped, a multi-class classification label tip\_class, and extracts a 1% random sample from the full joined dataset.

trans-unit.source: This query can be copied then pasted directly in the <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Studio</linkText><title></title> <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module for direct data ingestion from the SQL Server database instance in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This query can be copied then pasted directly in the <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Studio</linkText><title></title> <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module for direct data ingestion from the SQL Server database instance in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The query excludes records with incorrect (0, 0) coordinates.
trans-unit.target: The query excludes records with incorrect (0, 0) coordinates.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation using both Python and SQL queries against the SQL Server database created earlier.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will perform data exploration and feature generation using both Python and SQL queries against the SQL Server database created earlier.

trans-unit.source: A sample IPython notebook named machine-Learning-data-science-process-sql-story.ipynb is provided in the Sample IPython Notebooks folder.
trans-unit.target: A sample IPython notebook named machine-Learning-data-science-process-sql-story.ipynb is provided in the Sample IPython Notebooks folder.

trans-unit.source: This notebook is also available on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This notebook is also available on <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The recommended sequence when working with big data is the following:
trans-unit.target: The recommended sequence when working with big data is the following:

trans-unit.source: Read in a small sample of the data into an in-memory data frame.
trans-unit.target: Read in a small sample of the data into an in-memory data frame.

trans-unit.source: Perform some visualizations and explorations using the sampled data.
trans-unit.target: Perform some visualizations and explorations using the sampled data.

trans-unit.source: Experiment with feature engineering using the sampled data.
trans-unit.target: Experiment with feature engineering using the sampled data.

trans-unit.source: For larger data exploration, data manipulation and feature engineering, use Python to issue SQL Queries directly against the SQL Server database in the Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: For larger data exploration, data manipulation and feature engineering, use Python to issue SQL Queries directly against the SQL Server database in the Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: Decide the sample size to use for Azure Machine Learning model building.
trans-unit.target: Decide the sample size to use for Azure Machine Learning model building.

trans-unit.source: When ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:
trans-unit.target: When ready to proceed to Azure Machine Learning, you may either:

trans-unit.source: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Save the final SQL query to extract and sample the data and copy-paste the query directly into a <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: This method is demonstrated in the <linkText>Building Models in Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: This method is demonstrated in the <linkText>Building Models in Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new database table, then use the new table in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: Persist the sampled and engineered data you plan to use for model building in a new database table, then use the new table in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The following are a few data exploration, data visualization, and feature engineering examples.
trans-unit.target: The following are a few data exploration, data visualization, and feature engineering examples.

trans-unit.source: For more examples, see the sample SQL IPython notebook in the Sample IPython Notebooks folder.
trans-unit.target: For more examples, see the sample SQL IPython notebook in the Sample IPython Notebooks folder.

trans-unit.source: Initialize your database connection settings in the following variables:
trans-unit.target: Initialize your database connection settings in the following variables:

trans-unit.source: Total number of rows = 173179759
trans-unit.target: Total number of rows = 173179759

trans-unit.source: Total number of columns = 14
trans-unit.target: Total number of columns = 14

trans-unit.source: Time to read the sample table is 6.492000 seconds Number of rows and columns retrieved = (84952, 21)
trans-unit.target: Time to read the sample table is 6.492000 seconds Number of rows and columns retrieved = (84952, 21)

trans-unit.source: Now are ready to explore the sampled data.
trans-unit.target: Now are ready to explore the sampled data.

trans-unit.source: We start with looking at descriptive statistics for the trip\_distance (or any other) field(s):
trans-unit.target: We start with looking at descriptive statistics for the trip\_distance (or any other) field(s):

trans-unit.source: Next we look at the box plot for the trip distance to visualize the quantiles
trans-unit.target: Next we look at the box plot for the trip distance to visualize the quantiles

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #1</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #1</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #2</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #2</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this example, we bin the trip distance into five bins and visualize the binning results.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we bin the trip distance into five bins and visualize the binning results.

trans-unit.source: We can plot the above bin distribution in a bar or line plot as below
trans-unit.target: We can plot the above bin distribution in a bar or line plot as below

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #3</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #3</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #4</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #4</linkText>

trans-unit.source: We show scatter plot between trip\_time\_in\_secs and trip\_distance to see if there is any correlation
trans-unit.target: We show scatter plot between trip\_time\_in\_secs and trip\_distance to see if there is any correlation

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #6</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #6</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Similarly we can check the relationship between rate\_code and trip\_distance.
trans-unit.target: Similarly we can check the relationship between rate\_code and trip\_distance.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Plot #8</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Plot #8</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When preparing data for model building in Azure Machine Learning Studio, you may either decide on the SQL query to use directly in the Reader module or persist the engineered and sampled data in a new table, which you could use in the Reader[reader] module with a simple SELECT * FROM .
trans-unit.target: When preparing data for model building in Azure Machine Learning Studio, you may either decide on the SQL query to use directly in the Reader module or persist the engineered and sampled data in a new table, which you could use in the Reader[reader] module with a simple SELECT * FROM .

trans-unit.source: In this section we will create a new table to hold the sampled and engineered data.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will create a new table to hold the sampled and engineered data.

trans-unit.source: An example of a direct SQL query for model building is provided in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in SQL Server</linkText><title></title> section.
trans-unit.target: An example of a direct SQL query for model building is provided in the <linkText>Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in SQL Server</linkText><title></title> section.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we join the tables nyctaxi\_trip and nyctaxi\_fare, extract a 1% random sample, and persist the sampled data in a new table name nyctaxi\_one\_percent:
trans-unit.target: In this section, we join the tables nyctaxi\_trip and nyctaxi\_fare, extract a 1% random sample, and persist the sampled data in a new table name nyctaxi\_one\_percent:

trans-unit.source: In this section, we explore data distributions using the 1% sampled data which is persisted in the new table we created above.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we explore data distributions using the 1% sampled data which is persisted in the new table we created above.

trans-unit.source: Note that similar explorations can be performed using the original tables, optionally using TABLESAMPLE to limit the exploration sample or by limiting the results to a given time period using the pickup\_datetime partitions, as illustrated in the Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in SQL Server section.
trans-unit.target: Note that similar explorations can be performed using the original tables, optionally using TABLESAMPLE to limit the exploration sample or by limiting the results to a given time period using the pickup\_datetime partitions, as illustrated in the Data Exploration and Feature Engineering in SQL Server section.

trans-unit.source: In this section we will generate new labels and features directly using SQL queries, operating on the 1% sample table we created in the previous section.
trans-unit.target: In this section we will generate new labels and features directly using SQL queries, operating on the 1% sample table we created in the previous section.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, we generate two sets of labels to use for modeling:
trans-unit.target: In the following example, we generate two sets of labels to use for modeling:

trans-unit.source: Binary Class Labels tipped (predicting if a tip will be given)
trans-unit.target: Binary Class Labels tipped (predicting if a tip will be given)

trans-unit.source: Multiclass Labels tip\_class (predicting the tip bin or range)
trans-unit.target: Multiclass Labels tip\_class (predicting the tip bin or range)

trans-unit.source: This example transforms a categorical field into a numeric field by replacing each category with the count of its occurrences in the data.
trans-unit.target: This example transforms a categorical field into a numeric field by replacing each category with the count of its occurrences in the data.

trans-unit.source: This example transforms a continuous numeric field into preset category ranges, i.e., transform numeric field into a categorical field.
trans-unit.target: This example transforms a continuous numeric field into preset category ranges, i.e., transform numeric field into a categorical field.

trans-unit.source: This example breaks down the decimal representation of a latitude and/or longitude field into multiple region fields of different granularity, such as, country, city, town, block, etc. Note that the new geo-fields are not mapped to actual locations.
trans-unit.target: This example breaks down the decimal representation of a latitude and/or longitude field into multiple region fields of different granularity, such as, country, city, town, block, etc. Note that the new geo-fields are not mapped to actual locations.

trans-unit.source: For information on mapping geocode locations, see <linkText>Bing Maps REST Services</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on mapping geocode locations, see <linkText>Bing Maps REST Services</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We are now ready to proceed to model building and model deployment in <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: We are now ready to proceed to model building and model deployment in <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The data is ready for any of the prediction problems identified earlier, namely:
trans-unit.target: The data is ready for any of the prediction problems identified earlier, namely:

trans-unit.source: Binary classification: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Binary classification: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip paid, according to the previously defined classes.
trans-unit.target: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip paid, according to the previously defined classes.

trans-unit.source: Regression task: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Regression task: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: To begin the modeling exercise, log in to your Azure Machine Learning workspace.
trans-unit.target: To begin the modeling exercise, log in to your Azure Machine Learning workspace.

trans-unit.source: If you have not yet created a machine learning workspace, see <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you have not yet created a machine learning workspace, see <linkText>Create an Azure ML workspace</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To get started with Azure Machine Learning, see <linkText>What is Azure Machine Learning Studio?</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: To get started with Azure Machine Learning, see <linkText>What is Azure Machine Learning Studio?</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Log in to <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Studio</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Log in to <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Studio</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Studio Home page provides a wealth of information, videos, tutorials, links to the Modules Reference, and other resources.
trans-unit.target: The Studio Home page provides a wealth of information, videos, tutorials, links to the Modules Reference, and other resources.

trans-unit.source: Fore more information about Azure Machine Learning, consult the <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Documentation Center</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Fore more information about Azure Machine Learning, consult the <linkText>Azure Machine Learning Documentation Center</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A typical training experiment consists of the following:
trans-unit.target: A typical training experiment consists of the following:

trans-unit.source: Create a +NEW experiment.
trans-unit.target: Create a +NEW experiment.

trans-unit.source: Get the data to Azure ML.
trans-unit.target: Get the data to Azure ML.

trans-unit.source: Pre-process, transform and manipulate the data as needed.
trans-unit.target: Pre-process, transform and manipulate the data as needed.

trans-unit.source: Generate features as needed.
trans-unit.target: Generate features as needed.

trans-unit.source: Split the data into training/validation/testing datasets(or have separate datasets for each).
trans-unit.target: Split the data into training/validation/testing datasets(or have separate datasets for each).

trans-unit.source: Select one or more machine learning algorithms depending on the learning problem to solve.
trans-unit.target: Select one or more machine learning algorithms depending on the learning problem to solve.

trans-unit.source: E.g., binary classification, multiclass classification, regression.
trans-unit.target: E.g., binary classification, multiclass classification, regression.

trans-unit.source: Train one or more models using the training dataset.
trans-unit.target: Train one or more models using the training dataset.

trans-unit.source: Score the validation dataset using the trained model(s).
trans-unit.target: Score the validation dataset using the trained model(s).

trans-unit.source: Evaluate the model(s) to compute the relevant metrics for the learning problem.
trans-unit.target: Evaluate the model(s) to compute the relevant metrics for the learning problem.

trans-unit.source: Fine tune the model(s) and select the best model to deploy.
trans-unit.target: Fine tune the model(s) and select the best model to deploy.

trans-unit.source: In this exercise, we have already explored and engineered the data in SQL Server, and decided on the sample size to ingest in Azure ML.
trans-unit.target: In this exercise, we have already explored and engineered the data in SQL Server, and decided on the sample size to ingest in Azure ML.

trans-unit.source: To build one or more of the prediction models we decided:
trans-unit.target: To build one or more of the prediction models we decided:

trans-unit.source: Get the data to Azure ML using the Reader[reader] module, available in the Data Input and Output section.
trans-unit.target: Get the data to Azure ML using the Reader[reader] module, available in the Data Input and Output section.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module reference page.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module reference page.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure ML Reader</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure ML Reader</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Azure SQL Database as the Data source in the Properties panel.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure SQL Database as the Data source in the Properties panel.

trans-unit.source: Enter the database DNS name in the Database server name field. Format: tcp:,1433
trans-unit.target: Enter the database DNS name in the Database server name field. Format: tcp:,1433

trans-unit.source: Enter the Database name in the corresponding field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the Database name in the corresponding field.

trans-unit.source: Enter the SQL user name in the Server user aqccount name, and the password in the **Server user account password.
trans-unit.target: Enter the SQL user name in the Server user aqccount name, and the password in the **Server user account password.

trans-unit.source: Check Accept any server certificate option.
trans-unit.target: Check Accept any server certificate option.

trans-unit.source: In the Database query edit text area, paste the query which extracts the necessary database fields (including any computed fields such as the labels) and down samples the data to the desired sample size.
trans-unit.target: In the Database query edit text area, paste the query which extracts the necessary database fields (including any computed fields such as the labels) and down samples the data to the desired sample size.

trans-unit.source: An example of a binary classification experiment reading data directly from the SQL Server database is in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: An example of a binary classification experiment reading data directly from the SQL Server database is in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: Similar experiments can be constructed for multiclass classification and regression problems.
trans-unit.target: Similar experiments can be constructed for multiclass classification and regression problems.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure ML Train</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure ML Train</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the modeling data extraction and sampling query examples provided in previous sections, all labels for the three modeling exercises are included in the query.
trans-unit.target: In the modeling data extraction and sampling query examples provided in previous sections, all labels for the three modeling exercises are included in the query.

trans-unit.source: An important (required) step in each of the modeling exercises is to exclude the unnecessary labels for the other two problems, and any other target leaks.
trans-unit.target: An important (required) step in each of the modeling exercises is to exclude the unnecessary labels for the other two problems, and any other target leaks.

trans-unit.source: For e.g., when using binary classification, use the label tipped and exclude the fields tip\_class, tip\_amount, and total\_amount.
trans-unit.target: For e.g., when using binary classification, use the label tipped and exclude the fields tip\_class, tip\_amount, and total\_amount.

trans-unit.source: The latter are target leaks since they imply the tip paid.
trans-unit.target: The latter are target leaks since they imply the tip paid.

trans-unit.source: To exclude unnecessary columns and/or target leaks, you may use the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module or the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To exclude unnecessary columns and/or target leaks, you may use the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module or the <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> reference pages.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Metadata Editor[metadata-editor]</linkText><title></title> reference pages.

trans-unit.source: When your model is ready, you can easily deploy it as a web service directly from the experiment.
trans-unit.target: When your model is ready, you can easily deploy it as a web service directly from the experiment.

trans-unit.source: For more information about publishing Azure ML web services, see <linkText>Publish an Azure Machine Learning web service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about publishing Azure ML web services, see <linkText>Publish an Azure Machine Learning web service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To deploy a new web service, you need to:
trans-unit.target: To deploy a new web service, you need to:

trans-unit.source: Create a scoring experiment.
trans-unit.target: Create a scoring experiment.

trans-unit.source: Publish the web service.
trans-unit.target: Publish the web service.

trans-unit.source: To create a scoring experiment from a Finished training experiment, click CREATE SCORING EXPERIMENT in the lower action bar.
trans-unit.target: To create a scoring experiment from a Finished training experiment, click CREATE SCORING EXPERIMENT in the lower action bar.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Scoring</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Scoring</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning will attempt to create a scoring experiment based on the components of the training experiment.
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning will attempt to create a scoring experiment based on the components of the training experiment.

trans-unit.source: In particular, it will:
trans-unit.target: In particular, it will:

trans-unit.source: Save the trained model and remove the model training modules.
trans-unit.target: Save the trained model and remove the model training modules.

trans-unit.source: Identify a logical input port to represent the expected input data schema.
trans-unit.target: Identify a logical input port to represent the expected input data schema.

trans-unit.source: Identify a logical output port to represent the expected web service output schema.
trans-unit.target: Identify a logical output port to represent the expected web service output schema.

trans-unit.source: When the scoring experiment is created, review it and adjust as needed.
trans-unit.target: When the scoring experiment is created, review it and adjust as needed.

trans-unit.source: A typical adjustment is to replace the input dataset and/or query with one which excludes label fields, as these will not be available when the service is called.
trans-unit.target: A typical adjustment is to replace the input dataset and/or query with one which excludes label fields, as these will not be available when the service is called.

trans-unit.source: It is also a good practice to reduce the size of the input dataset and/or query to a few records, just enough to indicate the input schema.
trans-unit.target: It is also a good practice to reduce the size of the input dataset and/or query to a few records, just enough to indicate the input schema.

trans-unit.source: For the output port, it is common to exclude all input fields and only include the Scored Labels and Scored Probabilities in the output using the Project Columns[project-columns] module.
trans-unit.target: For the output port, it is common to exclude all input fields and only include the Scored Labels and Scored Probabilities in the output using the Project Columns[project-columns] module.

trans-unit.source: A sample scoring experiment is in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: A sample scoring experiment is in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: When ready to publish, click the PUBLISH WEB SERVICE button in the lower action bar.
trans-unit.target: When ready to publish, click the PUBLISH WEB SERVICE button in the lower action bar.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure ML Publish</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure ML Publish</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To recap, in this walkthrough tutorial, you have created an Azure data science environment, worked with a large public dataset all the way from data acquisition to model training and publishing of an Azure Machine Learning web service.
trans-unit.target: To recap, in this walkthrough tutorial, you have created an Azure data science environment, worked with a large public dataset all the way from data acquisition to model training and publishing of an Azure Machine Learning web service.

trans-unit.source: This sample walkthrough and its accompanying scripts and IPython notebook(s) are shared by Microsoft under the MIT license.
trans-unit.target: This sample walkthrough and its accompanying scripts and IPython notebook(s) are shared by Microsoft under the MIT license.

trans-unit.source: Please check the LICENSE.txt file in in the directory of the sample code on GitHub for more details.
trans-unit.target: Please check the LICENSE.txt file in in the directory of the sample code on GitHub for more details.

trans-unit.source: • Andrés Monroy NYC Taxi Trips Download Page • [FOILing NYC’s Taxi Trip Data by Chris Whong](http://chriswhong.com/open-data/foilnyctaxi/) • NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission Research and Statistics
